Description: Terracotta squatting ithyphallic figure playing double-pipes. A naked man or satyr modelled in the round and seated on a block, playing double pipes between which his large phallus rises; his head is lost and the elbows and right lower leg are damaged. He is corpulent, with a roll of flesh creased at his waist behind. The plain and rectangular plinth is injured in places, taking away the left foot. Solid; two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt with a grey-brown core and white inclusions. There are remains of an overall white dressing, with pink paint on the flesh areas.
Curator's comments: Very similar to GR1973,0501.31 (Bailey 2008, no. 3235), but not from the same mould. Similar to other Late Period to early Ptolemaic Harpocrates pieces found at Naukratis.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3234)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.189) (Phase 1)
